SMC219Y1-Y-20215.courseDescription: Designed to acquaint students with the essential notions of media studies, and to promote a conscious utilization of contemporary media. Starting with the preliminary definitions of media, mass, and communications, the student is invited to consider critically the cultural constructs created by modern media, from print to photography, filming, TV, computer and Internet.
SMC219Y1-Y-20215.breadthCategories: Creative and Cultural Representations (1), Society and its Institutions (3)

SMC228H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An historical introduction to the evolution of printing processes since Gutenberg. Attention is given to topics such as the mechanization of printing, the industrialization of the book chain since the nineteenth century, typography and publishing. Visits to rare book collections are an integral part of the course. Note: this course is not intended as a guide to self-publishing nor as a workshop on book making.

SMC229H1-S-20215.courseDescription: An introduction to the history of reading in western culture, from ancient Greece to the twenty-first century. Attention is given to topics such as the causes and effects of different modes of reading (silent or vocalized, intensive or extensive, educational or escapist), book clubs, censorship, and the ways in which readers have influenced cultural production.

SMC314H1-S-20215.courseDescription: A deeper examination of key cases in the development of media, such as the invention of movable type, the mechanization of the printing press, standardization of call number systems (Dewey, LC, etc.), the advent of radio, television and internet. Topics vary from year to year, according to the instructor.
SMC314H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Opportunities for class discussions via live webinars will be made available and are optional. Students need the ability to use power point and BB Collaborate.

SMC316H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Social media tools and platforms are deeply embedded in our contemporary lives. But what consequences do they have for how we think, how we feel, how we socialize, how we understand ourselves, and how our networked society and culture functions? Students in this course will explore, examine, and debate these questions with reference to their everyday experiences and current examples.
SMC316H1-S-20215.prerequisite: Enrolment priority for students enrolled in a Book and Media Studies program
SMC316H1-S-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Opportunities for class discussions via live webinars will be made available and are optional.

SMC317H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Applying the thought of key media theorists (Innis, McLuhan, Habermas, Fiske, etc.) to the historical symbiosis between music and media, students in this course explore communications from oral storytelling to YouTube, as well as examine the relationship between music and other arts.
SMC317H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: An exploration of diverse media narratives to address cultural approaches to trauma.
SMC317H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Opportunities for class discussions via live webinars will be made available and are optional. Students need the ability to use power point and BB Collaborate.

SMC380H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An opportunity for students to pursue an independent course of study not otherwise available in the Faculty of Arts and Science. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SMC380H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Permission of the Principal of St. Michael's College. Normally restricted to students who have completed at least ten full courses with a CGPA of at least 2.5. Application forms are available in the St. Michael's College Principal's Office. A completed application signed by the student and by the supervising instructor must be submitted to the St. Michael's College Principal's Office for approval; at least one month before the beginning of the semester.
SMC380H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For "E" indicator courses, please contact the SMC Program Administrator at smc.programs@utoronto.ca.
SMC380H1-F-20215.deliveryInstructions: Meetings will be determined in consultation with your supervisor and will happen online or in-person if advisable.

SMC386H1-F-20215.courseDescription: Credit is offered to a student doing an internship with a media organization formally recognized as a partner of St. Michael's College and the Book and Media Studies Program. A faculty supervisor assesses and assigns the necessary written component cognate to the internship.
SMC386H1-F-20215.prerequisite: Permission of the Program Coordinator and Principal
SMC386H1-F-20215.webTimetableInstructions: For "E" indicator courses, please contact the SMC Program Administrator at smc.programs@utoronto.ca.

SMC457H1-S-20215.courseDescription: Based on a professor's research project currently in progress, this course will enable an undergraduate student to play a useful role in the project while receiving hands-on training in research. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SMC457H1-S-20215.webTimetableInstructions: Meetings will be determined in consultation with your supervisor and will happen online or in-person if advisable.

SMC465H1-F-20215.courseDescription: An advanced seminar on McLuhan's theory of technology, perception, and social media.
